Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (Landlord and Te.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (Landlord and Tenant)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (Landlord and Te.proposition: Under Massachusetts law and common law principles of landlord-tenant relationships, a tenant has a right to the peaceful and quiet use and enjoyment of leased premises, free from substantial interference caused by the landlord’s failure to act where the landlord has notice and the ability to control or abate the nuisance (see, e.g., Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant § 5.1 et seq.; 1A Powell on Real Property ¶ 5.03; Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (Landlord and Tenant); see also Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing tenants’ rights in the context of housing conditions), Edwards v. Habib, 397 F.2d 687 (D.C. Cir. 1968) (landlord liability for failure to protect against harassment/retaliatory conduct); Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (implied warranty of habitability and landlord duties); see generally Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant § 15.1 (covenant of quiet enjoyment)).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239 (Summary Process.proposition: Venue is proper in Somerville District Court because the real property at issue is located in Somerville (see Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186; ch. 239).

Edwards v. Habib, 397 F.2d 687 (D.C. Cir.proposition: Under Massachusetts law and common law principles of landlord-tenant relationships, a tenant has a right to the peaceful and quiet use and enjoyment of leased premises, free from substantial interference caused by the landlord’s failure to act where the landlord has notice and the ability to control or abate the nuisance (see, e.g., Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant § 5.1 et seq.; 1A Powell on Real Property ¶ 5.03; Mass. Edwards v. Habib, 397 F.2d 687 (D.C. Cir.case_name: Yvonne C. Edwards v. Nathan Habib
Edwards v. Habib, 397 F.2d 687 (D.C. Cir.support_reasoning: Edwards v. Habib concerns a federal statutory-interpretation question about whether Congress, in authorizing housing code enforcement and providing an eviction mechanism, allows retaliatory eviction; it does not address Massachusetts law, the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, or landlord liability for failure to abate nuisances. The quoted concurrence only states that Congress cannot be read to permit retaliatory eviction, which is a different concept from a tenant’s right to be free of substantial interference from the landlord’s failure to act. Thus, this case does not support the specific proposition cited.
Edwards v. Habib, 397 F.2d 687 (D.C. Cir.relevant_excerpt: “The issue of statutory construction presented in this case has never seemed to me to be a difficult one… A Congress which authorizes housing code promulgation and enforcement clearly cannot be taken to have excluded retaliatory eviction of the kind here alleged as a defense under a routine statutory eviction mechanism also provided by Congress.”

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law and common law principles of landlord-tenant relationships, a tenant has a right to the peaceful and quiet use and enjoyment of leased premises, free from substantial interference caused by the landlord’s failure to act where the landlord has notice and the ability to control or abate the nuisance (see, e.g., Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant § 5.1 et seq.; 1A Powell on Real Property ¶ 5.03; Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (Landlord and Tenant); see also Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing tenants’ rights in the context of housing conditions), Edwards v. Habib, 397 F.2d 687 (D.C. Cir. 1968) (landlord liability for failure to protect against harassment/retaliatory conduct); Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (implied warranty of habitability and landlord duties); see generally Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant § 15.1 (covenant of quiet enjoyment)).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The case is a Vermont Supreme Court decision recognizing and defining an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, treating the lease as a contract with interdependent covenants. It does not discuss Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or nuisance-based liability for substantial interference with use and enjoyment caused by a landlord’s failure to abate conditions. Its focus is on habitability and rent/ damages remedies, not on quiet enjoyment or nuisance principles, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. This warranty of habitability is implied in tenancies for a specific period or at will. Additionally, the implied warranty of habitability covers all latent and patent defects in the essential facilities of the residential unit.

Coppinger v. Finnegan, 14 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Coppinger v. Finnegan, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 109 (1982)
Coppinger v. Finnegan, 14 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts decisions recognize that tenants may recover damages for substantial interference with quiet enjoyment and for the landlord’s failure to act to remedy known disturbances. See, e.g., Coppinger v. Finnegan, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 109 (1982) (recognizing tenant protections against landlord inaction), and cases construing landlord duties under ch. 186 and related Massachusetts authorities.
Coppinger v. Finnegan, 14 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Bell v. Zoning Board of Appeals
Coppinger v. Finnegan, 14 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This opinion is a zoning/land-use case about whether a private tennis court complies with a municipal zoning bylaw. It does not involve a landlord–tenant relationship, quiet enjoyment, or damages for disturbances, nor does it discuss G.L. c. 186 or any landlord duties. Using Coppinger v. Finnegan here to support tenant recovery for interference with quiet enjoyment and landlord inaction is inaccurate; the case is unrelated to that proposition.
Coppinger v. Finnegan, 14 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: The Bells…are owners of a large parcel of land… In this part of their land, the Bells have sought to build, and now have built, a tennis court for use by them, their family, and guests. The interveners and others have objected, asserting that such a court is in violation of the Cohasset zoning by-law. … We proceed to consider whether the by-law, reasonably interpreted, permits the tennis court proposed in the plan of May 29, 1980.
